titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Elizabeth Bishop Papers, circa 1880-2023 (bulk 1929-1979)
titlestmt.author: Inventory prepared by the Archives and Special Collections Library, Vassar College Libraries

publicationstmt.publisher: Archives and Special Collections Library, Vassar College Libraries

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Elizabeth Clarke February 2007.

did.head: Collection Summary
did.physdesc: 42.6 cubic feet (125 boxes, 22 boxes of photocopies and reproductions)

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Archives and Special Collections Library, Vassar College Libraries

did.abstract: Correspondence, diaries, notebooks, manuscripts and drafts, memorabilia, artwork, publications, and photographs relating to Bishop's personal and professional life. Also, letters, minutes, contracts, and financial records from her teaching and publishing activities, 1943-1979; manuscripts, typescripts, drafts, revisions, and fragments of her poetry and prose writings, 1929-1979; Vassar student notebooks, travel diaries, notes from her 17-year residence in Brazil, and family information, 1931-1977; manuscripts, typescripts, articles, essays, and poetry by or about other writers, especially Robert Lowell, 1925-1979; and printed poetry, prose, reviews, and articles by or about Bishop.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Elizabeth Bishop (8 February 1911 - 6 October 1979) was a Pulitzer-Prize winning poet, Consultant in Poetry to the Library of Congress, and winner of the National Book Award. She was born in Worcester, Massachusetts in 1911 but after her father's death and mother's hospitalization was raised by other relatives, and her fondest childhood memories were of Nova Scotia and Cape Cod. In 1934 Bishop graduated from Vassar College. In addition to working on the school newspaper, The Vassar Miscellany, Bishop founded a literary magazine, Con Spirito, with fellow students Mary McCarthy, Eleanor Clark, and Muriel Rukeyser. Following graduation, Bishop spent several years traveling. She stayed in New York, as well as various cities in Europe and North Africa, but she finally found a home in Key West, Florida, where she made several influential friends and found inspiration for many of her most significant poems. When World War II turned Key West into a military command center, Bishop packed her suitcase again. After brief periods in Washington, an artists' colony in upstate New York and a return to New York City, Bishop set out on what was supposed to be a voyage around the world by ship. But in Rio de Janeiro, the first port, she had an allergic reaction to the fruit of a cashew and was nursed back to health by Maria Carlota de Macedo Soares. She and "Lota" fell in love and Bishop made Brazil her home for the next 17 years. She returned to the States only when in the mid 1960s it became financially necessary. She accepted teaching positions at the University of Washington, then Harvard, followed seven years later by New York University, and just prior to her death, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Elizabeth Bishop Papers consist of correspondence, personal papers, working papers, notebooks, diaries, and memorabilia as well as a substantial amount of material by and about her friends and colleagues. Among the collection are over 3,500 pages of drafts of poems and prose, over 200 letters from Marianne Moore written between 1935 and 1969 discussing their work and mutual friends; and over 200 letters from Robert Lowell written between 1947 and 1976 discussing his work and that of Bishop's and her influence on his work, as well as the work of other writers including Ezra Pound, William Carlos Williams, W.H. Auden, Sylvia Plath, Flannery O'Connor, and Mary McCarthy.

Other correspondents include: Leonie Adams, John Ashbery, John Berryman, Harold Bloom, Robert Bly, Louise Bogan, John Malcolm Brinnin, Seamus Heaney, Anthony Hecht, Randall Jarrell, Archibald MacLeish, James Merrill, Henry Moore, Howard Moss, Octavio Paz, Katherine Anne Porter, Muriel Rukeyser, Anne Sexton, Mark Strand, May Swenson, Allen Tate, Dylan Thomas, Alice B. Toklas, John Updike, Eudora Welty, and Edmund Wilson.

The collection also contains letters from Elizabeth Bishop to James Merrill, Pearl Kazin Bell, Loren MacIver and Lloyd Frankenberg, Anny Baumann, and other friends and relatives. Of particular note are letters to and from Maria Carlota "Lota" de Macedo Soares.

The Elizabeth Bishop Papers also include the only extant typescript of her 1939 poem, "Pleasure Seas," photographs, slides, watercolors by Elizabeth Bishop, diplomas, academic hoods, citations, and her Brazilian oil lamp.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research according to the regulations of the Vassar College Archives and Special Collections Library. However, researchers will generally be required to use photocopies and not original material due to frequent research requests and the collection's fragility.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Permission to quote (publish) from unpublished or previously published material must be obtained in writing from Farrar, Straus, Giroux. Additional permissions must be obtained as described in the regulations of the Vassar College Archives and Special Collections Library.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Translations, transcriptions, and annotations: Translations by Lilli Correia de Araújo of eight letters written in Portuguese by Lota de Macedo Soares to Bishop in 1964 are available. Also available are transcriptions and annotations by David Hoak of: 1) correspondence from Lota to Bishop in 1967, and 2) letters from Bishop to Ruth Foster.

p.archref: Elizabeth Bishop Estate and Posthumous Events Collection
Iannucci Modern American Literature Manuscript Collection

relatedmaterial.p: Vassar College Alumnae/i Authors Files — Elizabeth Bishop Files

p.extref: Photocopies of Bishop's letters to Marianne Moore are on deposit at Vassar from the Marianne Moore Papers at the Rosenbach Library and Museum, Philadelphia, PA.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Separated Material: 5 boxes of galleys and other material related to work published after Bishop's death were moved to the Elizabeth Bishop Estate and Posthumous Events Collection in 2012. This does not include Bishop's original drafts, but rather the work done by Alice and Bishop's editors after Bishop's death. The boxes included were 50-51 (The Collected Prose) and 61-63 (The Complete Poems). One additional typescript was also moved: "A Trip to Vigia."
Separated Material: Some material relating to celebrations of Bishop and her work were moved to the Elizabeth Bishop Estate and Posthumous Events Collection in April 2012.
Separated Material: The card index to Bishop's library was removed from Box 111 and placed in the card catalog in the Archives and Special Collections office.

Literature and Writing

odd.head: Encoding Information
odd.p: Encoded by Elizabeth Clarke, February 2007. Last updated by Emma Gronbeck, May 2025.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Letters from identifiable correspondents in the "Miscellaneous," "Christmas Card," and "Fan Mail" folders were pulled and individually foldered (Boxes 21-22) by Laura Streett, September 2010.

Photographic reproductions of Bishop's slides of Brazil (Boxes 101-102) were added to the collection by Emma Gronbeck, January 2024. Finding aid was updated to include a series (Series XVI) for all preservation photocopies and reproductions included as part of the collection.
Ten items of realia belonging to Bishop were removed from the Vassar College Realia Collection and returned to the Bishop Papers (Boxes 129-131) by Emma Gronbeck, May 2025.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Purchase Sources Include: Alice H. Methfessel, Anny Baumann, Phyllis Sutherland, Linda Nemer, E. Wharton and Co., Glenn Horowitz, Bookseller; Katharine O. Sargent, Emanuel Brasil, Estella Pereira, Richard Levey, Irvine Huck, Philip Booth, H. E. Turlington Books, Lilli Correia de Araújo, James S. Jaffe Rare Books, the Portinari Family, and Gesoki Booksellers.

Gift Sources Include: An anonymous donor, James Merrill, Alice H. Methfessel, Pearl K. Bell, Howard Moss, Rollie McKenna, U.T. and Joseph Summers, Frani Blough Muser, the Margaret Bradley Sherman Library Fund (of Vassar College), Helen Muchnic, James Laughlin, Estate of Victor L. O. Chittick, Harriet Thomas Tompkins.
Additions to the collection since 2000 are located in boxes 112-128.

originalsloc.head: Location of Originals
originalsloc.p: Researchers may read photocopies of the Elizabeth Bishop letters to Marianne Moore from the Marianne Moore Papers that are on deposit here at Vassar courtesy of the Rosenbach Library and Museum. All permissions relating to this collection should be directed to the Rosenbach.
James Laughlin donated photocopies of the correspondence he received from Bishop; the original letters remain in his possession.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Elizabeth Bishop Papers, Archives and Special Collections Library, Vassar College Libraries.

Listed chronologically by date of publication, or if no date is available, alphabetically by title. Note: Dates in brackets indicate the date of publication not the date of creation

did.unittitle: Series VIII. TRAVEL JOURNALS AND NOTES,
Series X. BIOGRAPHICAL AND FAMILY DATA,

scopecontent.p: This series consists of photocopies and other reproductions of materials from the first fifteen series in this collection, as well as copies of letters from the Marianne Moore Papers at the Rosenbach Museum and Library. The majority of these photocopies were made at some point during the late 20th century in order to provide access to the papers while minimizing wear and tear to the originals. Enlarged photographic reproductions of Bishop's slides of Brazil are also included.
